column1: Ismail, N., Sallam, Y., Behery, R., & Al Boghdady, A. (2017). Cortical auditory evoked potentials in children who stutter. International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology, 97, 93-101. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijporl.2017.03.030
column2: 60 children, 30 non-stuttering children (control group) and 30 children who stutter (study group) ranging in severity from Bloodstien I to Bloodstien IV in the age range of 8–18 years.
column5: Children who stutter, ranging in severity from Bloodstien I to Bloodstien IV
column29: It has been hypothesized that impaired auditory processing influence the occurrence of stuttering. Also, it is suggested that speech perception in children who stutter differed from normal. Auditory processing should be investigated in children who stutter shortly after the onset of stuttering in order to evaluate the extent to which impaired auditory processing contributes to the development of stuttering. CAEPs provide the necessary temporal and spatial resolution to detect differences in auditory processing and the neural activity that is related or time-locked to the auditory stimulus. The primary goal of the present study was to determine the difference in latency and amplitude of P1-N2 complex between children who stutter and non-stuttering children in response to speech stimuli.

column41: This study investigates the cortical auditory evoked potentials (CAEPs) in children who stutter compared to non-stuttering children, focusing on the latency and amplitude of the P1-N2 complex in response to speech stimuli. The study aims to explore how auditory processing differences might contribute to stuttering, particularly in children with severe stuttering symptoms.

column2: 12 adults who stutter (AWS), 10 men and 2 women, aged 18-29 years
column5: 18 years and above; seeking treatment for stuttering; onset of developmental stuttering occurred before 10 years of age; SS must be greater than 2% at the initial pre-treatment assessment stage
column9: Percent of syllables stuttered (%SS); self-reported inventory scores; speech naturalness score evaluations
column41: This study describes a model for improving SLP education through intensive stuttering treatment delivered by students. Adults who stutter received treatment that significantly reduced stuttering and improved speech naturalness, demonstrating the effectiveness of student-delivered, evidence-based practice.
